topic.title: How to Install and run Zeronet on any Linux server like Raspberry Pi (zeronet seedbox, public proxy)
topic.body:
# This tutorial is outdated. See the up to date version [HERE](/1LfvE91ZF18jdG3wW62Dw7NtfTZh737KPL/?Topic:1605116535_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/How+to+Install+and+run+Zeronet+on+any+Linux+server+like+Raspberry+Pi+zeronet+seedbox+public+proxy)

Tutorial on how to Install and run Zeronet on any Linux computer like for example a on VPS, Raspberry Pi.
Minimal hardware requirements: according to [this](/Blog.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post:94) tutorial, ZN should be able to run on 1GHz ARM CPU and 512MB RAM.
Lists of VPS offers: http://lowendstock.com/ & http://vps-list.cryto.net/index.php?action=list
Or check Storage kind of VPS plans at https://openvz.io/ , https://www.time4vps.eu/storage-vps/ , http://www.ramnode.com/vps.php (check OpenVZ HDD plans)
If you do not hurry (can wait a few weeks) you can subscribe to [ovh watchlist](https://checkservers.ovh/), and try to catch once they restock popular cheap storage servers.
-
First [increase limit of open files](https://www.ecosia.org/search?q=linux+increase+open+files+limit) to something maybe like 10000
(i do: echo "\* hard nofile 10000" >> /etc/security/limits.conf)
-
Are you having python 3 available? Check output of the command: python --version;python3 --version
If it's not there try command: sudo apt-get install python3 2>/dev/null || yum install python3 2>/dev/null
("sudo: command not found" ? remove "sudo " from command or "apt-get install sudo"?)
-
Downloading and installing Python 3 version of the ZeroNet bundle including dependencies (ZN package that does not include dependencies is [here](/1HMLvnRWViMnuvZc5LK4Dm86sZNcSH1jdh/?Topic:1592407260_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/Outdated+tutorial+on+how+to+install+ZeroNet+package+without+bundled+dependencies)):
cd /home;wget --no-check-certificate -c https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet-linux/archive/dist-linux64/ZeroNet-py3-linux64.tar.gz -O - | tar -xz
mv ZeroNet\* zeronet;cd zeronet;chmod +x ZeroNet.sh;ls -l

-
Now you can launch zeronet with help parameter to see if it is working:
./ZeroNet.sh --help

maybe it will not work and you would have to launch it from root's session (command "sudo su") or allow all users to use python (security issue?) by executing: sudo chmod u+s /usr/bin/python3 /usr/bin/python2
-
sidenote: If above installation will not work, search the internet for the errors you have got. Some python2 and python3 installation commands are also in [this topic](/16Go5kc2U9Ff4jeaY8kYiDEgpMYdgyboPY/?Topic:3_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/Installing+python+2+Zeronet)
-
_OPTIONAL LINE (only for those with static IP & open port, [make server act as zeronet tracker](/Blog.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post:135:Changelog:+August+28,+2018)):_ mv core/plugins/disabled-Bootstrapper core/plugins/Bootstrapper
-
If you want to use multiple identities you can add "multiuser_local" to the zeronet.conf file and enable Multiuser plugin by renaming its folder, command: mv core/plugins/disabled-Multiuser core/plugins/Multiuser
For example my zeronet.conf looks like following (it is the command that creates the file):
> echo -e "[global]\nfileserver_port = 0\nui_ip = *\nui_port = 80\nmultiuser_local\noptional_limit = 90%\nautodownload_bigfile_size_limit = 200\nbigfile_size_limit = 1000" > zeronet.conf

In above command the ui_ip is important to make the zeronet's web UI (user interface) accessible via web browser and server IP address. If you're running ZN not as root, you may need to set ui_port to higher value like 8080 as ZN will fail to bind to lower than 1024 port. Note that if you're not using webserver/http service on your server, then now uninstall it now so it does not collide with zeronet's web server: apt remove apache\* httpd\* postfix\* sendmail\* 2>/dev/null || yum erase apache\* httpd\* postfix\* sendmail\* 2>/dev/null
_ _ _ _

**Enable Tor** (recommended to access significantly more peers etc.), follow: https://zeronet.io/docs/faq/#how-to-use-zeronet-with-tor
but in short, if you are logged in as a root, then following 3 commands should setup it:
1. sudo apt install tor -y 2>/dev/null || yum install epel-release -y;yum install tor 2>/dev/null;sudo pacman -S tor 2>/dev/null
2. sudo sed -i "s|#ControlPort|ControlPort|g" /etc/tor/torrc;sudo sed -i "s|#CookieAuthentication|CookieAuthentication|g" /etc/tor/torrc;sudo usermod -a -G debian-tor root 2>/dev/null||sudo usermod -a -G tor root 2>/dev/null;
3. chkconfig tor on 2>/dev/null||systemctl enable tor 2>/dev/null;**reboot**

!! If logged as root, then you may need to remove sudo from commands.
!! If not logged-in as root, then in above commands replace "root" by your username under which you will be launching the zeronet. Maybe you would need to [launch zeronet under superuser/sudo permissions](/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1580049334_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/Running+zeronet+py+without+sudo+results+in+failure+Permission+denied+Python+Pip).
The reboot command will restart your server.

If there will be still ERROR on ZeroHello page or in zeronet command output, then one may try this command:

toruser="$(ls -l /var/lib/tor|tail -n1|awk '{print $3}')" && for var in CacheDirectoryGroupReadable CookieAuthFileGroupReadable DataDirectoryGroupReadable ExtORPortCookieAuthFileGroupReadable;do if [ "$(grep -v \"#\" /etc/tor/torrc)" != \*"$var 1"\* ];then sed -i "/$var/d" /etc/tor/torrc && echo "$var 1" >> /etc/tor/torrc;fi;done;sed -i "/User /d" /etc/tor/torrc && echo "User $toruser" >> /etc/tor/torrc;sudo sed -i "s|#ControlPort|ControlPort|g" /etc/tor/torrc;sudo sed -i "s|#CookieAuthentication|CookieAuthentication|g" /etc/tor/torrc

_ _ _ _
To make **zeronet start after Linux boot**
run:
crontab -e
and then append new line (linux "vi" editor wants "a" key to allow text input):
> @reboot /bin/bash /home/zeronet/ZeroNet.sh &

Verify that paths really exist (which bash;ls -l /home/zeronet/ZeroNet.sh) and use existing path.
After pasting the text (i do mouse right click), then i do Ctrl+C/Ctrl+x to stop editting mode and then type ":wq!" (or "y") which will save changes and quit.

-
**To make zeronet start if it gets stopped**, run command:
vi /root/runZNifnotrunning
append into file:
> \#!/bin/bash
> if [[ "$(ps auxf|grep -iE 'start.py|zeronet.py|ZeroNet.sh'|grep -Ev 'grep|siteDownload'|wc -l)" == "0" ]];then
> /bin/bash /home/zeronet/ZeroNet.sh &
> fi

(again, update your paths if you have different)

then run command:
chmod 600 /root/runZNifnotrunning

then add new crontab file that will execute above created script every minute:
> echo -e "MAILTO=\"\"\n\* \* \* \* \* root /bin/bash /root/runZNifnotrunning 2&1>/dev/null" > /etc/cron.d/zn;chmod 600 /etc/cron.d/zn


ZN should be started by now. Open http://YOUR_SERVER_IP_ADDRESS in your browser
If it is not opening, try to run it manualy to see possible errors:
> /bin/bash /home/zeronet/ZeroNet.sh

For example my firewall blocked the connections, so i had [to fix it](https://serverfault.com/a/739465/189414).
Use search engine to find solutions for the errors.
Once fixed, ZN should start in 1 minute automaticaly and you should see ZN interface under http://YOUR_SERVER_IP_ADDRESS


note that anyone in the world who know your server IP can access the zeronet and play with it. To protect your zeronet, you can use [ui_restrict parameter or ui_password parameter after enabling ui_password plugin](/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1580247379_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/How+to+password+protect+Zeronet+server+proxy+web+interface).

FOLLOWING ARE **ANOTHER INTERESTING THINGS HOW TO MAKE YOUR SERVER MORE USEFUL**:
_ _ _ _

If you are having maybe more than 1TB of free disk space and want to seed all kind of files (incl. illegal), you may try to enable automatic downloading of all optional files on sites (on some sites tens of gigabytes) - zeronet should take care and try to keep only yours defined portion of the disk drive defined by the optional_limit config variable. It should delete most seeded files to keep the limit - just use zeronet.conf option: optional_limit = 90%
and it should maintain 10% disk space free. Related zeronet.conf options:
download_optional = auto

Take a note about also these config. options:
  --autodownload_bigfile_size_limit MB
                        Also download bigfiles smaller than this limit if help
                        distribute option is checked (default: 1)
  --bigfile_size_limit MB
                        Maximum size of downloaded big files (default: False)
  --multiuser_no_new_sites
                        Denies adding new sites by normal users (default:
                        False)

(Restart ZN to apply changes. More by command: ./ZeroNet.sh --help)

If you **want to help seed many (3200+) sites**, you can check [this page](/1HMLvnRWViMnuvZc5LK4Dm86sZNcSH1jdh/?Topic:1553085871_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/3212+zeronet+sites).

Can also come handy: [Linux bash script to periodicaly download sites recently added to "New ZeroNet Sites"](/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1546121685_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/Linux+bash+script+to+download+sites+recently+added+to+New+ZeroNet+Sites)
_ _ _ _

**Is your server located in home LAN?** If so and you want to use it as a primary zeronet access point without the need to install it on your desktop computer or android device? You may try to setup port forwarding so local (127.0.0.1:43110) IP gets forwarded/redirected to your server. Check Tusiko comment under [this post](/1FMGApV8HfFdq8wX8vvfn27twHhyFPVM7N/?Post:22:ZeroNet,+Tor+and+IPFS+on+a+Raspberry+Pi). Or you may try [Firefox Redirector plugin](/1LfvE91ZF18jdG3wW62Dw7NtfTZh737KPL/?Topic:1546086964_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/Automatic+redirect+URL+to+different+URL+domain+in+web+browser).
_ _ _ _

There are also another tutorials:
[Tutorial: Run ZeroNet in Android by Linuxdeploy](/1EiMAqhd6sMjPG2tznkkGXxhdwFBDdeqT9/?Post:73)
[Installing ZeroNet py3 version by Termux on Android](/1EiMAqhd6sMjPG2tznkkGXxhdwFBDdeqT9/?Post:93)

topic.title: Installing python 2 Zeronet
topic.body:
Python 2.x version of the ZeroNet does not contain many new features. But if you are unable or not willing to install py3 in parallel, then here are py2 commands that may help installing py2 Zeronet on Linux:

A) REDHAT/CENTOS: yum install epel-release -y;yum install wget python-pip python-devel
Note: you may want to [install python3](https://www.rosehosting.com/blog/how-to-install-python-3-6-4-on-centos-7/) to support latest zeronet
-
B) DEBIAN/UBUNTU: apt-get install wget python-dev python-pip python3-pip python-cffi libffi-dev
-
then install:
pip install --upgrade pip
pip install cffi --upgrade 2>/dev/null;pip2 install cffi --upgrade;pip3 install cffi --upgrade
pip install gevent --upgrade 2>/dev/null;pip2 install gevent --upgrade;pip3 install gevent --upgrade
pip install msgpack-python --upgrade 2>/dev/null;pip2 install msgpack-python --upgrade;pip3 install msgpack-python --upgrade
- - - - - -
IN CASE OF ERRORS, TRY:
A) redhat/centos: yum install python-cffi python-gevent python-msgpack
B) debian/ubuntu: apt-get install python-cffi python-gevent python-msgpack

- - - - - -

cd /home;wget https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/archive/master.tar.gz
-
tar -xzf master.tar.gz;rm -f master.tar.gz
mv ZeroNet-master zeronet;cd zeronet
python zeronet.py &

tail -n 50 -f logs/debug.log

- - - -
Another ideas and things to do are in the [main (python3) tutorial here](/16Go5kc2U9Ff4jeaY8kYiDEgpMYdgyboPY/?Topic:2_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/How+to+Install+and+run+Zeronet+on+a+Raspberry+Pi+or+any+Linux+computer)
! Note that if you decide to apply any solutions from python3 tutorial, make sure you do not forget to replace python3 commands by python. For example:
/usr/bin/python3 -> /usr/bin/python
"python3 zeronet.py" -> python zeronet.py

to discover python binary, run command "python --version;python3 --version"
